citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
On the night of 6/23/23, at ~2:00 am, a 5-week-old male bat-eared fox died. The licensee woke to a gasping sound from
the fox within his kennel. The licensee stated that he found the fox laying on its side and its belly was gassed up and hard.
The licensee gave the fox a rectal suppository, thinking it may be bloated. The licensee stated that he did not call the
attending veterinarian because it was in the middle of the night, and it seemed like the fox was already dying. There is no
mention of suppositories on the program of veterinary care and the attending veterinarian did not instruct the licensee to
administer a suppository. Each dealer shall maintain programs of veterinary care that include the use of appropriate
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the availability of emergency, weekend and
holiday care. Administering substances that are not approved by a veterinarian may cause injury or harm to the animal
and should not be used on regulated animals.
***Correct starting 10/30/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
On the night of 6/23/23, at ~2:00 am, a 5-week-old male bat-eared fox died. The licensee woke to a gasping sound from 
the fox within his kennel. The licensee stated that he found the fox laying on its side and its belly was gassed up and hard. 
The licensee gave the fox a rectal suppository, thinking it may be bloated. The licensee stated that he did not call the 
attending veterinarian because it was in the middle of the night, and it seemed like the fox was already dying. There is no 
mention of suppositories on the program of veterinary care and the attending veterinarian did not instruct the licensee to 
administer a suppository. Each dealer shall maintain programs of veterinary care that include the use of appropriate 
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the availability of emergency, weekend and 
holiday care. Administering substances that are not approved by a veterinarian may cause injury or harm to the animal 
and should not be used on regulated animals.  
 
***Correct starting 10/30/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
 n
